titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Oversize LJS 62: Herbal in the tradition of Dioscorides

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Oversize LJS 62: Herbal in the tradition of Dioscorides are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Work on plants and their medicinal properties in 679 chapters, preceded by illustrations, a prologue, and a table of contents listing 697 chapters. The prologue attributes it to Dioscorides, Galen, and Isocrates; the work is very similar to the De materia medica of Dioscorides. With many notes added.

msItem.title: Herbal in the tradition of Dioscorides
Pen-and-wash drawings of medicinal plants and 2 drawings of Dioscorides, f. 1r
Prologue about plants and their medicinal virtues, f. 11r

supportDesc.extent: 121 leaves : 261 x 190 (210 x 130) mm. bound to 268 x 202 mm

collation.p: Paper, 121; 1-2⁴ 3² 4⁸(-2) 5⁴ 6¹⁰ 7¹² 8²⁴(-1) 9¹⁰(-1) 10¹⁰(-4, outer 2 bifolia) 11⁸(-2) 12¹⁰(-2) 13⁸(-1) 14¹³(?) 15⁸(-2, central bifolium) 16¹; text of the herbal (f. 31-121) has early pagination in ink, 1-66, 69-90, 97-108, 113-114, 117-124, 127-146, 149-165, [v], 166-187, 192-199, upper outer corners.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in Greek cursive minuscule script.

decoDesc.decoNote: 71 pen-and-wash drawings of medicinal plants (f. 1r-10v); pen-and-wash illustrations of Dioscorides and a companion collecting plants in bags (f. 1v) and Dioscorides and Galen (f. 4v); headings, captions, small initials, and large initials (sometimes with flourishes and extensions; for example, f. 82 (p. 117-118)) in red.

binding.p: Possibly 17th-century Greek blind-stamped calf over pasteboards; some leaves detached or almost detached.

origin.p: Written in the eastern Mediterranean in the 15th century.

history.provenance: Sold at auction at Sotheby's, 10 Dec. 1996, lot 61, to Lawrence J. Schoenberg.
Deposit by Lawrence J. Schoenberg and Barbara Brizdle, 2011.
